intro: Phoradendron leucocarpum, commonly known as the white-fruited mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and white, fleshy berries that contain the seeds. The plant relies on its host for water and some nutrients, while it produces its own carbohydrates through photosynthesis. It is native to parts of Central and South America, where it thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. Its ecological role includes providing food for birds and other animals that consume its berries.
